articles.headline: The Shrewd Shopper Carries a Smartphone
articles.snippet: Apps for Black Friday shoppers are now loaded with planning tools, prices and directions to parking spots.
articles.abstract: Apps for Black Friday shoppers are now loaded with planning tools, prices and directions to parking spots.
articles.lead_paragraph: This Black Friday, to the tech-aware go the spoils.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: As BMW Is Put to the Test, Its Plans Are Years Ahead
articles.snippet: Norbert Reithofer, who became the BMW chief executive in 2006, has delivered consistent profit through two crises and is becoming something of an icon of the revival of German industry.
articles.abstract: Norbert Reithofer, who became the BMW chief executive in 2006, has delivered consistent profit through two crises and is becoming something of an icon of the revival of German industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — In 1987, a recent engineering graduate named Norbert Reithofer wrote a treatise that in retrospect reads like a manifesto for the German economy. The only way manufacturers in a high-cost country with few natural resources could survive, he argued, was by becoming the most flexible and efficient in the world.

articles.headline: Tax Reform Might Start With a Look Back to ’86
articles.snippet: Taking a page from the Reagan administration and the development of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 may help the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: Taking a page from the Reagan administration and the development of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 may help the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: “A tax that places significantly different burdens on taxpayers in similar economic circumstances is not fair. For example, if two similar families have the same income, they should ordinarily pay roughly the same amount of income tax, regardless of the sources or uses of that income.”

articles.headline: New Trading Case Casts a Deeper Shadow on a Hedge Fund Mogul
articles.snippet: Evidence suggests that Steven A. Cohen participated in trades that the government says illegally used insider information, but he has not been charged.
articles.abstract: Evidence suggests that Steven A. Cohen participated in trades that the government says illegally used insider information, but he has not been charged.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2010, the billionaire hedge fund manager Steven A. Cohen gave a rare interview to Vanity Fair. He said that he wanted to combat persistent rumors that his firm, SAC Capital Advisors, routinely violated securities laws by trading on confidential information.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Peter J. Henning

articles.headline:
For Israel, Gaza Conflict Is Test for an Iran
Confrontation
articles.snippet: Israel’s exchange with Hamas was something of a practice run for any future armed face-off with Iran, featuring improved rockets that can reach Jerusalem and new antimissile systems to counter them.
articles.abstract: Israel’s exchange with Hamas was something of a practice run for any future armed face-off with Iran, featuring improved rockets that can reach Jerusalem and new antimissile systems to counter them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The conflict that ended, for now, in a cease-fire between Hamas and Israel seemed like the latest episode in a periodic showdown. But there was a second, strategic agenda unfolding, according to American and Israeli officials: The exchange was something of a practice run for any future armed confrontation with Iran, featuring improved rockets that can reach Jerusalem and new antimissile systems to counter them.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Crackdown in Quebec: ‘Le Gap’ Won’t Do
articles.snippet: A reinterpretation of the province’s 1977 language law has led to stricter rules on company signs not rendered in French and to a lawsuit by six American retailers.
articles.abstract: A reinterpretation of the province’s 1977 language law has led to stricter rules on company signs not rendered in French and to a lawsuit by six American retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GATINEAU, Quebec — The southern gentleman with the distinctive tie who looms above the entrance to a fast-food restaurant here is immediately recognizable to any American. The outlet’s name, PFK, however, might be a bit of a puzzle. And not far away on Boulevard Maloney, a busy street lined with shopping malls, sits another familiar sight: a red and white big-box store filled with binders, photocopier paper and desks. But the name, Bureau en Gros, might not ring a bell.

articles.headline: One-Party Control Opens States to Partisan Rush
articles.snippet: At least 37 states will soon be under single-party control, the most in six decades, raising the prospect that bold partisan agendas will flourish.
articles.abstract: At least 37 states will soon be under single-party control, the most in six decades, raising the prospect that bold partisan agendas will flourish.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Come January, more than two-thirds of the states will be under single-party control, raising the prospect that bold partisan agendas — on both ends of the political spectrum — will flourish over the next couple of years.

articles.headline: Jeb Bush in 2016? Not Too Early for Chatter
articles.snippet: Republicans are looking for a candidate who can help the party become more inclusive without ceding conservative principles.
articles.abstract: Republicans are looking for a candidate who can help the party become more inclusive without ceding conservative principles.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — Now that the Obama and Romney campaigns have closed their headquarters in Chicago and Boston, the attention of the political world is shifting to an office suite tucked behind the colonnades of the Biltmore Hotel complex here.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Tension and Confusion Linger in Gaza Strip After Cease-Fire
articles.snippet: The fatal shooting of a Palestinian man did not fracture the cease-fire that ended eight days of fighting between Hamas and Israel. But it did showcase the confusion that remains over the deal.
articles.abstract: The fatal shooting of a Palestinian man did not fracture the cease-fire that ended eight days of fighting between Hamas and Israel. But it did showcase the confusion that remains over the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza Strip — In the 12 years that he has lived here in the Abassam neighborhood adjacent to Gaza’s eastern border, Eyad Qudaih said, he had never ventured more than 20 yards east of his white stucco home because Israel said the area was off limits.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Clashes Break Out After Morsi Seizes New Power in Egypt
articles.snippet: Thousands of protesters chanted for the downfall of President Mohamed Morsi’s government in Cairo, while others ransacked the offices of the president’s former party in other cities.
articles.abstract: Thousands of protesters chanted for the downfall of President Mohamed Morsi’s government in Cairo, while others ransacked the offices of the president’s former party in other cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Protests erupted across Egypt on Friday, as opponents of President Mohamed Morsi clashed with his supporters over a presidential edict that gave him unchecked authority and polarized an already divided nation while raising a specter, the president’s critics charged, of a return to autocracy.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick
